tool.name: Reactome GSA Analysis

exit_code.description: Tool failed with a non-zero exit code.

tool.command: Rscript ${__tool_directory__}/reactome_analysis.R --dataset '$dataset' --data_type '$data_type' --annotation '$annotation' --method='$analysis_method' --use_interactors='$use_interactors' --include_disease_pathways='$include_disease_pathways' --pathways_output_file='$pathways' --entities_found_output_file='$entities_found' --entities_not_found_output_file='$entities_not_found' --pdf_output_file='$pdf_output' --json_output_file='$json_output' --excel_output_file='$excel_output' --comparison_factor='$comparison_factor' --reference_group='$reference_group' --comparison_group='$comparison_group' #if $analysis_method == "PADOG": --sample_groups='$sample_groups' --discrete_normalisation_function='$discrete_normalisation_function' --continuous_normalisation_function='$continuous_normalisation_function' #elif $analysis_method == "Camera": --discrete_normalisation_function='$discrete_normalisation_function' --continuous_normalisation_function='$continuous_normalisation_function' #elif $analysis_method == "ssGSEA": --pathways_to_include='$pathways_to_include' --min_pathway_size='$min_pathway_size' --max_pathway_size='$max_pathway_size' #else: echo "Unknown analysis method: $analysis_method" exit 1 #end if

param.name: dataset
param.label: Dataset
param.help: The dataset to be used for the analysis. The dataset must be a tabular file with the first column containing the gene/protein identifiers and the remaining columns containing the expression values. The first row should contain the sample names. The file should be tab-separated or comma-separated.

param.name: data_type
param.label: Data type
param.help: The type of data to be used for the analysis. The options are RNA-seq, Proteomics, or both.

param.name: annotation
param.label: Annotations
param.help: The annotation file should be a tabular file with the first column containing the sample names, one of the other columns containing the sample group information (reference/comparison) and the remaining columns containing any additional sample properties. The first row should contain the annotation names. The file should be tab-separated or comma-separated.

param.name: sample_groups
param.label: Sample groups
param.help: Specifies the sample property name that holds the sample group information. This parameter should be used for matched-pair analysis. If used, every sample must occur exactly twice, once for each of the analysis groups

param.name: discrete_normalisation_function
param.label: Discrete normalisation function
param.help: The normalisation function to use for raw RNA-seq read counts and raw Proteomics spectral counts

param.name: continuous_normalisation_function
param.label: Continuous normalisation function
param.help: The normalisation function to use proteomics intensity data. Note that it is generally advised that normalisation is performed on the PSM or peptide level and not on the protein level.

param.name: discrete_normalisation_function
param.label: Discrete normalisation function
param.help: The normalisation function to use for raw RNA-seq read counts and raw Proteomics spectral counts

param.name: continuous_normalisation_function
param.label: Continuous normalisation function
param.help: The normalisation function to use proteomics intensity data. Note that it is generally advised that normalisation is performed on the PSM or peptide level and not on the protein level.

param.name: pathways_to_include
param.label: Pathways
param.help: A comma delimited list of pathways to include in the analysis. All other pathways will be ignored.

param.name: min_pathway_size
param.label: Minimum pathway size
param.help: The minimum pathway size (determined as the number of submitted gnes mapped to that pathway) to include a pathway in the analysis.

param.name: max_pathway_size
param.label: Maximum pathway size
param.help: The maximum pathway size (determined as the number of submitted gnes mapped to that pathway) to include a pathway in the analysis.

param.name: use_interactors
param.label: Use interactors
param.help: Indicates whether interactors from IntAct should be used to extend REACTOME's pathways in the analysis

param.name: include_disease_pathways
param.label: Include disease pathways
param.help: Disease pathways in Reactome may lead to a skewed analysis result

param.name: max_missing_values
param.label: Max missing values
param.help: The maximum (relative) number of missing values within one comparison group before a gene/protein is removed form the analysis. If no comparison groups are defined, the number of missing values across all samples is used. Must be between 0-1

param.name: comparison_factor
param.label: Comparison factor
param.help: Comparison factor is the column from your annotation distinguishing the 2 groups to compare, the reference and the comparison group.

param.name: reference_group
param.label: Reference group
param.help: The baseline group against which other groups are compared. It usually represents the standard or default condition.

param.name: comparison_group
param.label: Comparison group
param.help: The group being compared to the reference group to assess differences or effects.

param.name: covariates
param.label: Covariates
param.help: Comma separated list of variables that may influence the outcome but are not the main variable of interest. These are included in the statistical models to adjust for effects and improve accuracy.

tool.help:
`Reactome <https://reactome.org>`_ is a manually-curated and peer-reviewed database of pathways and reactions in human biology.
Analyse Gene Expression (ReactomeGSA) -------------------------------------
This “Analyse Gene Expression” or ReactomeGSA resource provides comparative pathway analyses of multi-omics datasets. It allows researchers to uncover the functional relevance of a list of genes, associated with quantitative data, in the context of biological pathways and processes.
The ideal identifiers to use are:
* UniProt IDs for proteins * ChEBI IDs for small molecules * HGNC gene symbols or ENSEMBL IDs for DNA/RNA molecules
These are our main external reference sources for proteins and small molecules.
In Reactome, we offer three gene-set enrichment analysis algorithms:
PADOG: Pathway Analysis with Down-weighting of Overlapping Genes ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
- It corrects for **gene set redundancy**; some pathways share many genes, which can bias results. - Instead of treating all genes equally, PADOG down-weights genes that appear in multiple pathways, making the analysis less biased by highly represented genes. - Works well in cases where overlapping genes skew enrichment scores in traditional methods.
CAMERA: Correlation Adjusted Mean Rank ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
- It adjusts for **inter-gene** correlation in gene sets. - Traditional enrichment approaches assume genes are independent, but in reality, co-expressed genes within a pathway tend to be correlated. - CAMERA corrects for this by adjusting the statistical testing, making it more reliable when genes within pathways have strong dependencies. - Works well for datasets where gene co-expression is expected, for example, in transcriptomic data.
ssGSEA: Single-sample Gene Set Enrichment Analysis ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
- ssGSEA calculates an **enrichment score** for each gene set in individual samples. - It does not rely on ranking differentially expressed genes across conditions but rather assigns an enrichment score per sample based on the expression of genes in a pathway. - This makes it useful for single-sample comparisons, such as identifying pathway activity in individual patients or cell types. - Works well for single-cell or single-sample datasets.
More Information ---------------- Visit the `Reactome User Guide <https://reactome.org/userguide>`_ for detailed documentation about each tool.
For more information: visit our Youtube channel for an `Introduction to Reactome <https://youtu.be/cA7lQACsgZk>`_!
